titleStmt.title: James H. Swan et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG9402

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p: To his Excellency B Magoffin Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your petitioners would respectfully represent that they have been informed that J H Powell recently a citizen of the city of Memphis, state of Tennessee has been sent to the Penitentiary of the state of Kentucky from McCracken Co, for one year on a charge of larceny. Your petitioners state that they have been informed that said Powell's mind was impaired before he let the state of Tennessee on a visit to Kentucky in the summer of 1860, and that fact could have been easily established could the trial if the trial had been when the witnesses could have been obtained The petitioners, some of them from their own knowledge of Mr Powell, and others from information upon which they rely, believe that said Powell was an honest correct and industrious citizen up to the time where he visited Ky in the past summer. They therefore pray your Excellency to exercise your clemency in restoring said Powell to his distressed family, -- & petitioners
will ever pray &c.

James. H. Swan
Depty. Us, Marshall
John, L, Webb
C, W, Mallory
R. Sigler
J, Halstead
W R McClelland
J C Ward
F A Park.
S B Newell
